clinical_study.brief_title: Natural Orifice Transluminal Endoscopic Surgery for Colorectal Cancer
clinical_study.official_title: Natural Orifice Transluminal Endoscopic Surgery for Colorectal Cancer

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to assess different hybrid natural orifice transluminal endoscopic surgery techniques in management of colorectal cancer as regard: feasibility of the technique, short term oncologic outcome and functional outcome.

detailed_description.textblock: Intervention will be done by conventional laparoscopy and transanal endoscopy (TEO or Gelpoint platform), patients are divided into two arms to compare different natural orifice techniques in resection of colorectal cancer.

primary_outcome.description: Rate of conversion to classic laparoscopy or to open laparotomy.
time taken from starting operation till patient wake up

secondary_outcome.measure: Grading of quality and completeness of mesorectal excision
secondary_outcome.description: It is a composite outcome where result will appear as either complete, near complete or incomplete. Criteria in (shape, coning, presence of defects and circumferential safety margin) will be integrated to categorize it.
either free or infiltrated with tumor by histopathology examination.
incidence of local and distant outcomes and disease free survival
assessing fecal incontinence using Kirwan's grading score

arm_group.description: Conventional laparoscopic resection of colorectal cancer with natural orifice specimen extraction
Laparoscopic assisted transanal endoscopic resection of rectal cancer

intervention.description: Conventional laparoscopic resection of colorectal cancer is done then specimen is extracted through natural orifice (anal or vaginal orifice).

Endoscopic phase: Transanal platform is inserted into the rectum, and pneumorectum is established. The lumen is occluded below the level of the tumor. The avascular ''oncologic'' presacral plane is entered posteriorly, and dissection proceeds cephalad in the total mesorectal excision planes. Next, the abdominal cavity is entered at the peritoneal reﬂection. The superior rectal artery is divided. The rectal stump then is reﬂected into the abdominal cavity, and retrograde dissection is performed until the procedure is limited by instrument length. Laparoscopic phase: Colon mobilization, lymph node dissection, and mesenteric excision are performed laparoscopically. Mobilization of the splenic ﬂexure is done if needed.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Medically fit patient.
2. Non metastatic pathologically proven sigmoid colon cancer.
3. Non metastatic pathologically proven rectal cancer.
4. Patient continent for stool.
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Patients with American Society of Anesthesiologist (ASA) score 4 and 5.
2. Patients with cardiac or chest problems that cannot withstand insufflation.
3. Unresectable tumors (defined as those who cannot be resected without a high likelihood of leaving microscopic or gross residual disease at the local site because of tumor adherence or fixation).
4. Obstructed or perforated cancer.
5. Patients with metastatic colorectal cancer.
6. Incontinent patients.
